item.title: How to Get XP & Level Up Fast in Dying Light: The Beast
item.description:
If you want to feel truly powerful in Dying Light: The Beast, one of the best ways to do that is to grind out XP and level up quickly. Doing so will unlock skill points, which can be used to make you more effective in combat, traversal easier, and generally make you even more of a one-man army. The problem is, grinding out XP can be pretty slow-going, especially if you like to explore the map and not just beeline through the main questline. Fortunately, I've found a cheese that makes it incredibly easy to grind out XP and level up fast, so you can storm your way through Dying Light: The Beast .

How to Level Up Fast in Dying Light: The Beast

There are a few different ways you can earn more XP than the standard amount you will get for defeating enemies during the day. Obviously, completing main quests will net large chunks of XP, but if you're below the recommended level for the next one you've got to take on, that's not an option. Outside of completing the main quests, the best way to grind XP and level up fast involves making use of the nighttime and your Beast Mode.

To most effectively use this method, you'll want to have the Beast Controlled skill unlocked in your Beast skill tree. This allows you to control when your Beast Mode is activated. However, if you don't have this, you can still follow the method below, but it'll take you longer, and it's more difficult to get all the timings right.

Night Time Controlled Beast Method

First, make your way to the Town Hall and sleep in the bed until nighttime. Now, exit out the front door and charge your Beast Meter by dodging normal zombies' attacks. Once you've filled your meter, trigger a Chase by looking for a Volatile. These are the zombies with the red glowing eyes and they are pretty common. All you need to do is make sure that one sees you and that the 'Chase Started' message appears on your screen.

At this point, run back towards the Town Hall (if you're not already there) and activate your Beast Mode. Kill the Volatiles, and whenever you need a break to heal up or when Beast Mode ends, retreat under the UV lights at the front gate of the Town Hall. This will stop the zombies from attacking you and can even weaken them, making it easy to take them down if you're able to activate your Beast Mode again.

For every Volatile that you kill, you'll earn 500+ XP. This is a huge amount of XP to farm, especially if you're able to wipe out a few Volatiles in a single chase with your Beast Mode.

As mentioned above, it is possible to do this before unlocking the Controlled Beast skill, but it does require some good timing on your part. All you need to do is charge up enough of your Beast Mode bar, and then trigger a chase and hit a Volatile a few times under the safety of the UV lights to force yourself into Beast Mode. Then it's a case of killing the Volatiles and any other zombies that join the chase with ease. While the smaller zombies won't net you as much XP as a Volatile, killing them at night will still earn you more than doing so in the day would.

Avoid Dying

Regardless of whether you use the Controlled Beast method above or not, the main piece of advice is to avoid dying as much as possible. Each time you die, you'll lose XP, and for me, that ranged from around 100-500XP. This can quickly rack up and really slow down your leveling progress if you continue to die once or twice during each main or side quest, or as you're exploring the world. If you're not feeling confident about surviving an encounter, try and escape. Find somewhere safe to heal up and get your way back to a Safe Point as quickly as possible.

What's the Max Level Cap in Dying Light: The Beast?

There aren't that many levels for players to grind out in Dying Light: The Beast , as the max level cap is 15. While there aren't many levels, the grind to get that XP from just completing quests can be quite slow-going, but with the method outlined above, you'll be able to get it done way before you reach the end of the story.

8 /10

Dying Light: The Beast

item.title: Path of Exile 2: How to Reset Instances
item.description:
The world of Path of Exile 2 is separated by maps that players can access by progressing from one area to another. When players enter a new map, a new instance is created for a limited amount of time. All creatures, items, and locations within that instance remain static for as long as it remains live.

While players have the option of waiting out an instance’s lifetime (typically 8-15 minutes) in order to reset a map, there is a way to manually reset them as well. Here is how the process works.

How to Reset Instances in Path of Exile 2

In Path of Exile 2 , you can reset an instance by opening the world map at a Waypoint, selecting a map node, and pressing CTRL + Left Click (PC) , Triangle (PlayStation) , or Y (Xbox) . On PC, you can select a map node by clicking on it, whereas on consoles, it only requires highlighting the desired map.

Using these hotkeys brings up the Instance Manager , a menu that allows players to start a new instance and lists all currently active ones. If you’ve entered a map recently, you will be able to choose between re-entering a previous instance or creating a new one. Selecting the latter option will place you in a new version of the selected map, which also resets all map progression, monsters, checkpoints, and map layout.

You can only open a new instance when accessing the world map menu via a Waypoint.

How Do Instances Work in Path of Exile 2?

All instances in Path of Exile 2 are on a timer . Once that timer runs out, that instance will disappear if players are not actively inside it. If you create a new instance for any given map, the previous instance of that map will still remain active for as long as its timer hasn’t run out, and will be accessible from the Instance Manager menu.

Typically, a map lasts between 8-15 minutes , as indicated by the Instance Manager. However, the exact time limit varies from server to server and depends on traffic. Less populated servers often have longer timers. You can check exactly how long an instance will last from the Manager as well.

Maps are randomly generated in PoE 2 , but their general layout remains the same.

Can You Reset Endgame Maps in Path of Exile 2?

Technically, yes, but not in the same manner. The method detailed above only works in Path of Exile 2 ’s campaign. In the endgame, the Atlas maps can only be accessed using Waystones at the Map Device; pressing CTRL + Left Click on a node won’t do anything.

To reset an instance in the endgame, you have to use a new Waystone to enter the node via the Map Device . If this is done at a map node that is already active with portals open, those portals will disappear, and new ones will appear. Entering the map through the new portals will put you in a new instance.

GGG has implemented this limitation into the endgame in order to prevent players from simply redoing a lucrative map over and over, as that would break the balance of the game.

9 /10

Path of Exile II

item.title: Dying Light The Beast: Best Skills to Get First
item.description:
As you start out in Dying Light: The Beast fighting your way through the hordes of the undead can be tiring work. While it's sometimes better to just run away from a fight, other times you'll need to face the threat head-on. Regardless of whether you're escaping or engaging zombies in a fight, there are some skills in Dying Light: The Beast you should get first to make the early hours of the game that little bit easier.

The Best Early Game Skills in Dying Light: The Beast

Dying Light: The Beast's skill trees require players to unlock skills in some sort of order. That means that you'll need to unlock those closest to the center before you can unlock those that extend further out in each direction. While this means that you're fairly limited to which skills you should get first, there are a handful that you should prioritize unlocking before others.

  • Active Landing (Agility Skill)
  • Dash (Agility Skill)
  • Enemy Jump (Agility Skill)
  • Charged Kick (Power Skill)
  • Power Shot (Power Skill)
  • Stealth Expert (Survival Skill)
  • Flamethrower (Survival Skill)
  • Advanced Grenades (Survival Skill)
  • Grenade Launcher (Survival Skill)

Active Landing

While it might not sound glamorous, being able to jump from pretty much any height and not take any fall damage as long as you press B/Circle just before hitting the ground can come in really useful when escaping a Chase during the night. It can also save an XP loss (and some embarrassment) if you misjudge a gap when heading to a quest objective and would otherwise plummet to your death.

Dash

A simple but effective skill, Dash allows you to move faster while running by pressing and holding L3. This comes in particualrly useful if you're alerted a Volatile during nighttime and triggered a chase, as it can give you the boost you need to just keep out of harm's reach. Keep in mind, however, that you'll need to carefully manage your Stamina, as it can't be used if you run out.

Enemy Jump

Another great skill for avoiding taking damage, Enemy Jump allows you to jump off enemies while you're dashing by pressing the RB button. This is particularly useful if you find yourself in an open area with no objects or buildings nearby that you can use to dodge enemies in close quarters.

Charged Kick

Unlocking Charged Kick requires you to unlock Dropkick first, but it's this skill that is more useful during the early hours. Being able to deal increased damage and push enemies further away with a kick press and hold of the A/X button comes in particularly useful if you're finding yourself getting overwhelmed.

It also uses less stamina than Dropkick, which admittedly works slightly better for clearing a bit of space if you find yourself getting swarmed. However, with the Dropkick you end up on the ground and it takes time to get back up. With a Charged Kick, you can knock enemies off rooftops, clear a bit of space, and still have the mobility to quickly escape.

Power Shot

Given how limited ammo for guns can be throughout the majority of your time in Dying Light: The Beast unlocking a skill that can help your bow deal bonus damage as well as inflicting piercing is well worth picking up as soon as possible. It does require you to perfectly time your shot, but once you've used the bow for a while, this will become second nature.

Stealth Expert

If you've run out of healing items or don't have a weapon in good condition, sometimes it's better to just sneak past enemies, or perform a stealth takedown by creeping up behind them. With Stealth Expert, enemies will take more time to notice you. It essentially makes the stealth elements of the gameplay more forgiving, which can come in clutch when faced with large crowds of dormant zombies just waiting to be alerted to your presence.

Flamethrower

The Flamethrower is easily one of the best weapons you can get early on in Dying Light: The Beast , and potentially in the entire game. It's an absolute beast for crowd control, setting enemies ablaze and dealing chip damage that'll soon have undead and human enemies alike collapsing to the ground.

Unlocking the skill will unlock the crafting recipe, but after a few hours in the game, chances are you'll have picked up all the resources you need to craft it anyway. Once that's done, as long as you keep your fuel topped up, you'll always be ready to set a crowd of the undead ablaze in a matter of seconds should you start to get overwhelmed.

To craft the Flamethrower, you'll need: 100 Scraps, 10 Weights, 3 Oxidizers, and 1 Fuel.

Advanced Grenades

While this comes along a little later in the Survival skill tree, if you're unlocked the other skills on this list already, chances are you'll almost be ready to unlock it anyway. Advanced Grenades grants you the ability to craft the Flash Grenade, Pipe Bomb, and Gas Grenade. Much like the flamethrower, these are great options for crowd controlling enemies. However, if you're looking for something that's particularly useful against the more intelligent human enemies, flash grenades are going to quickly become your best friend.

Grenade Launcher

What's better than having a flamethrower in your arsenal? Having a flamethrower and a grenade launcher. While the flamethrower is great for taking out enemies that have got a little too close for comfort, the grenade launcher is perfect for taking out crowds of enemies that are a little further away. Plus, it has the added benefit of allowing you to craft UV Grenades, which can keep Volatiles and Virals at bay in a way that no other weapon in the game can.

8 /10

Dying Light: The Beast

item.title: How to Get the Blade Blaster in Fortnite
item.description:
The Power Rangers are already in Fortnite , and Megazord is set to debut as a giant mech kaiju, but why not have the power of the Power Rangers within your hands? Battle Royale players are treated to the Blade Blaster, a Power Rangers pistol that can zap enemies and return them to the lobby. This powerful weapon has its own way to be obtained, so don't expect to find it in chests or on the floor. Below, players can find out exactly how they can get the Blade Blaster, along with gameplay so you can see if it's worth using.

How to Get the Blade Blaster

Blade Blaster Locations

The Blade Blaster can only be obtained from Bunkers. These Bunkers are scattered across the map in specific areas listed below, but it's worth noting that only 2 of these Bunkers will be active per game. Players can open the Bunkers by acquiring Rank A for O.X.R., which is easily achieved by killing bugs and eliminating other players, so venture to Dystopia City, The Hive, Ranger's Ruin, and Demon's Debris to get an A rank before other players. Here's where you can find the Bunkers to get the Blade Blaster:

  • South fo Dystopia City
  • West of O.X.R. HQ
  • North of Shiny Shafts
  • South of Foxy Floodgate

Check your map once you hit Rank A to see where your Bunkers are, and then access them to unlock the vault and find the treasure. The Blade Blaster is locked behind a display case within the Bunker, and players can interact with it to claim the weapon for free.

Blade Baster Stats & Gameplay (Is It Any Good?)

  • A dual-mode pistol: fires quick, snappy shots in hip-fire, and powerful explosive rounds when aiming down sights.

Splash Damage

26

ADS Damage

65

ADS Headshot Damage

94

Hip-Fire Damage

39

Hip-Fire Headshot Damage

68

Fire Rate

4.3

The Blade Blaster is a battery-powered Pistol, meaning it has its own dedicated ammunition. Players have 100 shots with the Blade Blaster, and once the battery is empty, the weapon is useless and can no longer be used. This Pistol has two firing modes, the first being hip-fire. The hip-fire mode deals less damage, but at a quicker fire rate, whereas aiming with the Pistol sees more damage, better accuracy, and slower fire time. Players should use the Blade Blaster if they're after a Pistol that has the power of a DMR and SMG in one small package.

item.title: PSA: Change This Dying Light: The Beast Setting When You Get Behind the Wheel
item.description:
While it's not the first time driving has been implemented in the Dying Light series, Dying Light: The Beast is the first to emphasize it to the degree that it does. This is, of course, due in large part to its sizable open world of Castor Woods, which has an unprecedented amount of open space and therefore requires players to travel across the map more efficiently. Rather than merely hopping across rooftops, players are often encouraged to hop into a nearby truck instead for a safer yet more expensive way of getting from one point to the next.

However, there is one setting change players should make once they finally do get behind the wheel in Dying Light: The Beast . It's a setting that might not be immediately noticeable either, especially when players are surrounded by a horde of infected and simply trying to get away. But implementing this change could mean the difference between life and death, between the vehicle being damaged to the point of exploding and the player successfully making it to their destination.

Dying Light: The Beast's Driving Is Best in Third-Person

First-Person Driving Is Immersive But More Difficult to Control

Upon getting into a truck in Dying Light: The Beast , players might simply start the vehicle and begin driving in first-person without considering whether there's an option to change the perspective. Again, some of this might be due to panic, but it also may be the fact that first-person is the most immersive way to drive in Dying Light: The Beast , in addition to the fact that it's fun, fairly easy, and can still get players to where they're going without too much trouble. In these moments, Techland's history with racing games really shows itself, as driving here is intuitive, responsive, and all-around satisfying.

That being said, Dying Light: The Beast 's first-person driving camera isn't without the caveat of making the vehicle a bit more difficult to control. Firstly, players will encounter numerous zombies in Dying Light: The Beast as they make their way through Castor Woods from behind the wheel of a park ranger truck, and running over those infected will temporarily obstruct their view. Virals will also occasionally leap onto the hood of the truck, not only preventing players from seeing the road ahead but also attacking their windshield. Secondly, hitting any major bump while in first-person can really throw things off for players who are on a tight schedule, like when a quest has a time limit, or they're participating in a race.

Third-Person Driving Allows for a Better View of Surroundings

Fortunately, these limitations are preventable with the option to change the camera to third-person while driving in Dying Light: The Beast . Again, it's not immediately noticeable, as players first need to pull up the controls once they get in a vehicle and then locate the option on the list. And while it's not as immersive as driving in first-person can be, it's still a much more efficient way of ensuring the vehicle and the player inside it make it to their destination in one piece.

Where players might benefit most from the third-person driving camera is during the game's races. Initially, there are three races that unlock via a certain quest line in Dying Light: The Beast , but several more open up once that quest line is completed that are even more difficult. Attempting to complete those, in particular, with the first-person camera active can feel impossible at times, but with the click of a bumper or the press of a key, the third-person camera allows players to get a better view of their surroundings so they can not only complete those races but also achieve the best times.

8 /10

Dying Light: The Beast
